explanation.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Jeder digitale Dienst wird mit Elektrizität betrieben. Unternehmen, die digitale Dienstleistungen anbieten, haben daher die Verantwortung, den Fußabdruck ihrer Dienstleistungen zu verringern. Man kann sich \"Cloud\"-Dienste als gemeinsam genutzte (virtuelle) Server vorstellen, die mit großer Flexibilität genutzt werden können. Da diese Cloud-Server von vielen Unternehmen gemeinsam genutzt und oft von High-Tech-Unternehmen entwickelt werden, erreichen sie eine Energieeffizienz, die 5-6x höher ist als bei herkömmlichen Vor-Ort-Diensten. Im Hinblick auf den CO₂ Fußabdruck der Anwendungen bedeutet dies, dass es im Allgemeinen besser ist, die digitalen Dienste in der Cloud zu betreiben, als eigene Server zu mieten. Solange diese Rechenzentren jedoch nicht zu 100 % mit erneuerbarer Energie betrieben werden, verursachen sie erhebliche CO₂ Emissionen.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Warum Ökostrom nicht immer so grün ist, wie wir denken","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Eine Frage, die sich Menschen, die ihren Energieversorger zu Hause auf einen ökologischen Tarif umgestellt haben, oft stellt, ist, ob der Strom, der aus der Steckdose kommt, jetzt tatsächlich anders ist oder nicht. Die Wahrheit ist, dass dies nicht der Fall ist, denn man verbraucht immer noch dieselbe Energie, die die Nachbarn verbrauchen. Er enthält immer noch den gleichen Energiemix, auch wenn man gerade \"grünen\" Strom gekauft hat. Warum ist das so? Nun, die Wahrheit ist, dass es keinen Sinn machen würde, die Energie, die man gekauft hat, zu einem nach Hause zu transportieren. Es würde im Grunde genommen einen separaten Transport und separate Kabel für den \"eigenen\" Strom und Energieverluste auf dem Weg dorthin erfordern. Stattdessen kauft der Energieversorger also auf den Energiemärkten Ökostrom ein. Wenn man sein Haus tatsächlich mit Ökostrom betreiben will, baut man am besten einen eigenen kleinen Energiepark (Sonne, Wind) im Garten auf. Dasselbe Prinzip gilt für Rechenzentrums- und Cloud-Anbieter auf der ganzen Welt. Viele von ihnen behaupten, ihre Rechenzentren klimaneutral zu betreiben, aber es gibt einige grundlegende Unterschiede zu dem, was dies tatsächlich bedeutet. Aus einer vereinfachten Sicht gibt es 3 verschiedene Arten der Klimaneutralität für Rechenzentren.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Stufe 1:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" Der Cloud-Anbieter kauft \"Renewable Energy Certificates\" (entbündelte RECs), um die Menge an \"nicht-grüner\" Energie auszugleichen, die sein Rechenzentrum verbraucht hat. Diese Zertifikate werden auf einem offenen Markt gehandelt und sind in der Regel sehr billig. Sie beschleunigen den Energiewandel nicht wirklich, da sie in der Regel bestehende Kraftwerke finanzieren (geringe Zusätzlichkeit > kein Ersatz für fossile Kraftwerke).","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Stufe 2:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" Der Cloud-Anbieter kauft nicht nur Zertifikate, sondern tatsächlich die Lieferung von Ökostrom (PPAs / gebündelte RECs) direkt von einem Kraftwerk für erneuerbare Energien ins lokale Netz, um die Menge an \"nicht-grüner\" Energie, die sein Rechenzentrum verbraucht hat, zu kompensieren. Im besten Fall finanziert das PPA ein neues oder noch zu bauendes Kraftwerk (hohe Zusätzlichkeit), so dass das Netz tatsächlich \"grüner\" wird..","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Stufe 3:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" Der Cloud-Anbieter betreibt das gesamte Rechenzentrum rund um die Uhr mit tatsächlicher erneuerbarer Energie. Dazu muss das gesamte lokale Netz, an dass das Rechenzentrum angeschlossen ist, einen sehr hohen Anteil an erneuerbarer Energie aufweisen, und die PPAs für lokale Ökostromanlagen müssen zu jeder Tageszeit den Stromverbrauch des Rechenzentrums übersteigen. Dies ist der heilige Gral der \"Grünen Wolke\". Es gibt nur sehr wenige Orte auf der Erde, wo dies heute möglich ist. Google nähert sich diesem Ziel mit einem seiner Rechenzentren in Finnland (97% erneuerbar 24/7).","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Was wir empfehlen","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Wie zu Beginn erwähnt, empfehlen wir generell, die digitalen Dienste in die Cloud zu verlagern und den Betrieb von Servern vor Ort nach Möglichkeit einzustellen. Natürlich wird man sich fragen: In welche Coud sollen wir “umziehen”? Der Cloud-Markt in der westlichen Welt wird von einigen wenigen großen Akteuren dominiert. Die größten sind AWS, Microsoft und Google. Glücklicherweise haben sich alle dazu verpflichtet, ihre Rechenzentren in den nächsten 10 Jahren klimaneutral zu stellen. Doch wenn man sich ihre Bemühungen genauer ansieht, wird deutlich, dass sie ihre Nachhaltigkeitsziele mit unterschiedlichen Prioritäten verfolgen. Google ist der einzige Cloud-Anbieter, der sich verpflichtet hat, 24/7 erneuerbare Energien (Stufe 3) für alle seine Rechenzentren zu erreichen, und hat sogar einen Rahmen entwickelt, um dieses Ziel zu erreichen. Da die meisten alternativen \"grünen\" Hosting-Dienste immer noch an ihr lokales Energienetz angeschlossen sind und nicht über die Effizienz eines großen Cloud-Anbieters sowie über die finanziellen Mittel verfügen, um in ihre eigenen Wind- oder Solarparks zu investieren, ist es sehr wahrscheinlich, dass die Google Cloud einen deutlich geringeren Platzbedarf hat als jeder dieser Dienste. Google wie auch die anderen großen Cloud-Anbieter sollten dafür kritisiert werden, dass sie ihre Dienste auch großen Öl- und Kohlekonzernen anbieten, aber es kann kaum für ihre Bemühungen zur Minimierung des Platzbedarfs ihrer Rechenzentren beurteilt werden.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Microsoft Azure:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" Microsoft hat sich in den letzten Jahren zu sehr ehrgeizigen Klimazielen verpflichtet. Während sie nicht so früh wie Google mit ihren Klimabemühungen begonnen haben, investieren sie jetzt stark in die klimafreundliche Transformation ihrer Cloud. Microsoft Azure ist bereits heute zu 100% klimaneutral (höchstwahrscheinlich eine Mischung aus Stufe 1 und 2) und hat sich verpflichtet, bis 2030 klimanegativ zu werden.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"AWS:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" Von den 3 dominierenden Akteuren in Europa ist die AWS der größte und auch der sich am langsamsten verändernde. Alle anderen Rechenzentren werden zu etwa 30-50% mit erneuerbarer Energie betrieben. AWS hat sich verpflichtet, bis 2030 eine 100%ige Klimaneutralität zu erreichen. Da AWS der technisch fortschrittlichste Cloud-Anbieter ist, verlassen sich viele große Unternehmen auf ihre Dienste und können nicht einfach zu einem grüneren Konkurrenten wechseln. Wir empfehlen diesen Unternehmen daher, alle ihre Cloud-Dienste in die oben genannten “grünen” Regionen von AWS zu verlagern. Your corporate finance can influence the climate more than you think. Use this power:

  • Look at how the company capital is secured, such as where it gets its project financing and loans. Where possible, move this business to banks that refuse to invest in businesses dependent on fossil fuels.
  • Talk to your accountants. They can help set up systems to measure and manage climate related externalities. They can support your finance team in raising and allocating the funds your organization needs for transition and adaptation, embedding greenhouse gas (GHG) reductions within your organization’s decision-making processes, and accurately tracking and reporting performance against reduction targets.
  • If your company operates in the financial sector, ensure your financial investments support low carbon initiatives.

Use your purchasing power to influence industry:

  • Policies and codes: Set supply chain policies and codes aligned with your own environmental standards, as well as universal standards. Make these standards a consideration when selecting new suppliers, and part of your regular conversation with suppliers.
  • __Suppliers qualification and engagement: __Review all your suppliers and look to buy from companies that are also operating with climate emergency conditions guiding their strategy.   • Energy usage: Encourage your suppliers to switch to using renewable electricity and biogas.

  • Use reusable or recycled materials where possible.
  • Undertake a full Life Cycle Analysis (LCA) on your products.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Pay attention to the energy label: invest in A+++ equipment when you buy dishwashers, coffee machines, refrigerators, or air conditioners. Here you can check how much your appliance consumes and find more energy-efficient appliances.

It's important to keep these requirements for new purchases and your next office renovation. But it can make things worse if you change working equipment with new ones, just with better energy consumption. To make the right decision, compare the new equipment's footprint and how much energy you can save if you buy it.

One more thing: to increase your energy efficiency in the office, pay attention to the 'working temperature' of household appliances. The dishwasher cleans just as well at 50°C as at 70°C and most food stays as fresh at 7°C as it does at 5°C. With these small temperature changes, you can save both energy and CO2 emissions.

requirements.title: Mindful use of heating and air conditioning

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Some ways to decrease your HVAC energy consumption:

  • purchase equipment with thermostats or timers to prevent unnecessary overheating. Use natural gas or wood pellets instead of oil. Wood pellet boilers are now a good alternative to conventional systems,
  • reduce the room temperature. Rule of thumb: 6 percent energy and CO2 emissions are saved per degree,
  • switch on heating only when a room is occupied or turn down the heating during non-working hours,
  • optimize heating behavior, introduce the "window open = heating off" rule,
  • for air conditioning, use natural coolants such as hydrocarbons (HxCy), carbon dioxide (CO2), and ammonia (NH3) instead of regular refrigerants like R134a,
  • install double-pane windows to prevent heat escape.

You can find even more info here.

LED lights consume up to 90% less energy, are very durable, and there is no delay in reaching full brightness when switching them on. To go further, consider installing occupancy sensors, daylight dimmers, task lighting, etc. One of the biggest LED appliance sellers is InnoGreen. More info about low-energy lighting can be found here.

requirements.title: Automatic power-off for computers and lights

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Electrical appliances such as computers, printers, and laptops consume a lot of power in standby mode. For laptops and computers, use the power saving settings. This also applies to network printers, which can be automatically put into sleep mode when not used for a while.

Shut equipment off at night and install timers and automated controls for equipment, heating, cooling, and lighting to reduce energy consumption. You can find more info here.

Sensor lights in conference rooms also help to conserve energy when not in use.

Minimal requirements:

  • join the government bicycle subsidizing program, which allows employees to spend on bikes and equipment, tax-free, making a claimed saving of up to 42 per cent on the overall value. e.g. JobRad (DE) and CycleScheme (UK).
  • ask for commitment. At the beginning of spring, riders commit to a certain frequency (daily, weekly, monthly) of commutes by bike. High frequency riders get bigger bike subsidies if they fulfill their commuting goals for the year. Track riders over the next twelve months with an honor-system spreadsheet. If they meet their riding commitment, they receive their full subsidy as a year-end-bonus.

If you want to go the extra mile:

  • Invest in a basic maintenance and repair station. This could be as limited as a bike pump, multi-tool, and bin of replacement tubes, or a full setup with a truing stand and bike repair rack.
  • Offer a bike pool for your employees. All it requires is an up-front investment in a small collection of bikes – preferably low maintenance models with internal gearing – and geometry that scales well to a range of rider sizes. Establish your bike pool at the beginning of the calendar year and encourage riding with bonuses and incentives for participation.
  • Engage: track miles and ride frequency in an honor-system and organize monthly group rides.

requirements.title: Set specific climate-related goals and OKRs

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Set your company’s measurable “big” goals for the current year. Some examples:

  • become climate neutral on Scope 1 and 2,
  • become climate neutral including Scope 3,
  • reduce your carbon footprint by __% this year compared to the previous year,
  • improve your CO2 emissions per revenue, or CO2 emissions per employee ratio, etc.

Get a bit of inspiration for what climate-related goals the US’ biggest companies and many others have.

It’s even better if you can make these targets science-based. Science based targets are goals set by companies to reduce GHG emissions in line with the latest climate science suggestions to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement (limit global warming to 1.5% above pre-industrial level). These targets can be externally verified by signing up to the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) which is a collaboration between the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP), United Nations Global Compact (UNGC), World Resources Institute (WRI), and the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF). Understanding your carbon impact across your full value chain will be a key part of setting your target. This must extend to Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions.

Every quarter, plan specific OKRs or KPIs to implement some climate-positive actions, such as initiatives that you can find in the current action plan. Set the process to measure your footprint quarterly to track dynamics and make the right decisions.

In addition, you can use an environmental management system (EMS) to systematically set targets and monitor progress. It measures the impact of your business (input, output, and everything in between), identifies areas and assets that have a significant impact, assigns a point score to each, and creates a list of targets to work toward.

If you are ready to reconsider your business model, appoint a transition team. This team will set a new strategy for the business, which includes setting science based targets and steps for implementing changes to the business model. External input might be required if your in-house capability is limited.

  1. Start by identifying areas of conflict, or potential conflict, between your core business model and factors of potentially negative environmental impact (e.g. production of or reliance on fossil fuels or other finite resources).
  2. For each conflict, review ways in which the negative impact identified could be altered to become positive. In many cases this will require some radically creative thinking and a workshop environment.
  3. Facilitation by an outside expert could be useful. For example: If your company manufactures washing machine components, and you identify that your (finite) raw input material is likely to become scarcer (therefore more expensive) over the next 10 - 20 years, you could consider a move to a leasing model whereby you retain ownership of the component, lease it to your customer, and recover it for remanufacturing or reuse after it has reached end of life.
  4. It is vital to identify where your business has the biggest carbon impact. These departments should then be considered a priority. Remember, your biggest impact could be outside of your head office.

A “Green” team is a group of people working on reduction measures throughout your company. In most cases it’s their additional area of work, aside from their regular work. They are driven by personal values and interest in climate topics.

How to organize the team’s work:

  • conduct meetings at least once a month,
  • offer anyone to join, but ask for a commitment to actively participate,
  • invite senior-level colleagues, representing departments which influence your carbon footprint the most to this team,
  • if more than 10-12 people want to participate, build smaller sub-teams,
  • set objective goals and work on actions that have the biggest impact on your carbon footprint,
  • let all employees know your green team's plans and successes transparently and regularly.

• Develop and implement formal, and job-specific, training on key sustainability issues for all executives and employees, and facilitate coaching, mentoring, and networks for sustainability knowledge sharing.
  • Educate employees about the structure of your footprint and how they can reduce it.
  • Make sure that all new employees go through an induction process and training program to get them involved in your vision of sustainability strategy. It gives everyone a good grasp of what they’re here for and how they can contribute.

Once everyone buys into the vision, you can quantify the environmental impact of various things and bring them to people’s attention. Teams start to see that there are budget implications, staff implications, environmental implications, and resolving this one issue could potentially improve the situation.

Digital services are powered by and consumed through computers that run on electricity. In order to reduce the footprint of these services, we need to make sure that the underlying electricity is coming from renewable energy sources.
All digital services run either on cloud- or on-premise servers, that are powered by 100% renewable energy.

nodes.title: Move to a bank that puts sustainability first

requirements.title: Use a "green" bank for your corporate banking

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Your corporate finance can influence the climate more than you think. Use this power:

  • Look at how the company capital is secured, such as where it gets its project financing and loans. Where possible, move this business to banks that refuse to invest in businesses dependent on fossil fuels.
  • Talk to your accountants. They can help set up systems to measure and manage climate related externalities. They can support your finance team in raising and allocating the funds your organization needs for transition and adaptation, embedding greenhouse gas (GHG) reductions within your organization’s decision-making processes, and accurately tracking and reporting performance against reduction targets.
  • If your company operates in the financial sector, ensure your financial investments support low carbon initiatives.

nodes.title: Conscious energy consumption

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Pay attention to the energy label: invest in A+++ equipment when you buy dishwashers, coffee machines, refrigerators, or air conditioners. Here you can check how much your appliance consumes and find more energy-efficient appliances.

It's important to keep these requirements for new purchases and your next office renovation. But it can make things worse if you change working equipment with new ones, just with better energy consumption. To make the right decision, compare the new equipment's footprint and how much energy you can save if you buy it.

One more thing: to increase your energy efficiency in the office, pay attention to the 'working temperature' of household appliances. The dishwasher cleans just as well at 50°C as at 70°C and most food stays as fresh at 7°C as it does at 5°C. With these small temperature changes, you can save both energy and CO2 emissions.

requirements.title: Mindful use of heating and air conditioning

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Some ways to decrease your HVAC energy consumption:

  • purchase equipment with thermostats or timers to prevent unnecessary overheating. Use natural gas or wood pellets instead of oil. Wood pellet boilers are now a good alternative to conventional systems,
  • reduce the room temperature. Rule of thumb: 6 percent energy and CO2 emissions are saved per degree,
  • switch on heating only when a room is occupied or turn down the heating during non-working hours,
  • optimize heating behavior, introduce the "window open = heating off" rule,
  • for air conditioning, use natural coolants such as hydrocarbons (HxCy), carbon dioxide (CO2), and ammonia (NH3) instead of regular refrigerants like R134a,
  • install double-pane windows to prevent heat escape.

You can find even more info here.

LED lights consume up to 90% less energy, are very durable, and there is no delay in reaching full brightness when switching them on. To go further, consider installing occupancy sensors, daylight dimmers, task lighting, etc. One of the biggest LED appliance sellers is InnoGreen. More info about low-energy lighting can be found here.

requirements.title: Automatic power-off for computers and lights

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Electrical appliances such as computers, printers, and laptops consume a lot of power in standby mode. For laptops and computers, use the power saving settings. This also applies to network printers, which can be automatically put into sleep mode when not used for a while.

Shut equipment off at night and install timers and automated controls for equipment, heating, cooling, and lighting to reduce energy consumption. You can find more info here.

Sensor lights in conference rooms also help to conserve energy when not in use.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Make sure that:

  • you have a company-wide recovery and recycling program that includes: paper, cardboard, plastic, glass, metal, and composting
  • you recycle waste not only from the kitchen but also all papers in your working spaces, cartons at your warehouse, etc.
  • your utility service works with all types of waste after you separate it, so it goes into the correct waste sorting centers.

What you can do to print less:

  • implement electronic signature systems where possible
  • instead of printing reports before business meetings, use more screens in meeting rooms
  • decrease the amount of pages by reducing font or page border sizes of regularly printed documents: contracts, agreements, etc.
  • add a reminder to print less in your corporate signatures
  • as a default setting, double-sided printing in black and white is recommended.

Plus, you can recycle your printer cartridges using a free recycling box from Caritas.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Mark this action as completed if you will buy office supplies made from recycled materials, produced and delivered in an eco-friendly way from now on.

Recycled paper is 100% made from used paper, saving resources and water. Although the recycled paper is no longer pure white, it is also free of peroxides, sodium carbonate, and sodium hydroxide. These chemicals are used both in the production of fresh fibre paper and for bleaching paper. Recycled paper has two to three times lower energy consumption during production.

At Memo, EarthHero, or GreenPicks you can find all of your sustainable office supplies.

  • when you need to buy things for your new office, don't just pay attention to them being made of ‘natural’ materials, but also to their production footprint

  • buy beverages in returnable glass bottles,
  • buy office snacks in bigger packages with less plastic.

Install low-flow faucets, toilets, and urinals in your office. Low-flow should meet or exceed the following EPA WaterSense standards: faucets use a maximum of 1.5 gpm, toilets - max 1.28 gallons per flush.

Think about:

  • How can you inspire customers to follow lower-carbon lifestyles?
  • What is one meaningful action you can ask them to take today to respond to the climate emergency?
  • What information can you share with them to inspire immediate actions?

This isn’t about passing the buck to consumers, it’s about empowering them to make changes that, together, add up to a major impact. Most likely, customers are expecting you to take the lead.

Every business is different, and the answer will totally depend on your sector. Ariel got people to switch their washing machines to 30 degrees, and in a few short years, Oatly has transformed coffee culture with their ‘I can’t-believe-it’s-made-with-plants’ barista oat milk. What could you do through your product?

  • Community power. Engage in the creation and activation of shared solutions and commitments to drive wider economic change. Make it easy for green-active customers to share their stories. Use a positive and motivating tone instead of a frightening and demanding one.

Use your purchasing power to influence industry:

  • Policies and codes: Set supply chain policies and codes aligned with your own environmental standards, as well as universal standards. Make these standards a consideration when selecting new suppliers, and part of your regular conversation with suppliers.
  • __Suppliers qualification and engagement: __Review all your suppliers and look to buy from companies that are also operating with climate emergency conditions guiding their strategy. Gearing the supply chain to achieve the organization’s climate commitments is a key step. The goal must be to create a ‘coalition of the willing’. Here you can find an example of a questionnaire and some advice on how to engage suppliers.
  • Energy usage: Encourage your suppliers to switch to using renewable electricity and biogas.
  • Keep updated and cooperate: send an annual letter to all your suppliers to share details about your environmental policy updates and achievements in carbon footprint reduction. Conduct a supplier survey and offer suppliers a space to record comments and provide feedback.

Mark this action as complete if you have done qualification for at least a group of Significant Suppliers (who collectively represent approximately 80% of your purchases in currency terms). Significant Suppliers can include both suppliers of physical items and service providers like accountants and web designers.

Use responsible materials:

  • Review all the materials used in your manufacturing processes and shift to the most responsible (and least impactful) materials.
  • Use reusable or recycled materials where possible.
  • Undertake a full Life Cycle Analysis (LCA) on your products.
  • Improve the End-of-Life process for your product.

For a more in-depth guide on managing impact within your supply chain, you can check out Creating Impact Through Purchasing made by B Labs.

• Ask major carriers to measure and track their greenhouse gas emission reductions.
  • Improve efficiency of shipping (optimize loads, reduce and eliminate packaging). Increase loading efficiency.
  • Design logistical systems to prioritize efficient and low-carbon transportation modes and low-carbon fuel options, especially fleet electrification where feasible.

Zero Waste means designing and managing products and processes to systematically avoid and eliminate the volume and toxicity of waste and materials, conserve and recover all resources, and not burn or bury them.

  • Regularly monitor and record waste produced.
  • Define specific waste types that are a significant source of greenhouse gas emissions for your business, set a goal to reduce this waste. Build a Zero Waste Roadmap.
  • Educate your production chain managers and suppliers with materials from the Zero Waste International Alliance.
  • Get Zero Waste Certification to prove that you are environmentally responsible, resource efficient, and help turn waste into savings and additional income streams.

Measures of success in meeting this goal are outlined in the Zero Waste Business Principles. Businesses that achieve over 90% diversion of waste from landfills and incinerators are considered to be successful in achieving Zero Waste, or very close.

nodes.title: Develop sustainable management principles

requirements.title: Set specific climate-related goals and OKRs

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Set your company’s measurable “big” goals for the current year. Some examples:

  • become climate neutral on Scope 1 and 2,
  • become climate neutral including Scope 3,
  • reduce your carbon footprint by __% this year compared to the previous year,
  • improve your CO2 emissions per revenue, or CO2 emissions per employee ratio, etc.

Get a bit of inspiration for what climate-related goals the US’ biggest companies and many others have.

It’s even better if you can make these targets science-based. Science based targets are goals set by companies to reduce GHG emissions in line with the latest climate science suggestions to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement (limit global warming to 1.5% above pre-industrial level). These targets can be externally verified by signing up to the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) which is a collaboration between the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP), United Nations Global Compact (UNGC), World Resources Institute (WRI), and the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF). Understanding your carbon impact across your full value chain will be a key part of setting your target. This must extend to Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions.

Every quarter, plan specific OKRs or KPIs to implement some climate-positive actions, such as initiatives that you can find in the current action plan. Set the process to measure your footprint quarterly to track dynamics and make the right decisions.

In addition, you can use an environmental management system (EMS) to systematically set targets and monitor progress. It measures the impact of your business (input, output, and everything in between), identifies areas and assets that have a significant impact, assigns a point score to each, and creates a list of targets to work toward.

If you are ready to reconsider your business model, appoint a transition team. This team will set a new strategy for the business, which includes setting science based targets and steps for implementing changes to the business model. External input might be required if your in-house capability is limited.

  1. Start by identifying areas of conflict, or potential conflict, between your core business model and factors of potentially negative environmental impact (e.g. production of or reliance on fossil fuels or other finite resources).
  2. For each conflict, review ways in which the negative impact identified could be altered to become positive. In many cases this will require some radically creative thinking and a workshop environment.
  3. Facilitation by an outside expert could be useful. For example: If your company manufactures washing machine components, and you identify that your (finite) raw input material is likely to become scarcer (therefore more expensive) over the next 10 - 20 years, you could consider a move to a leasing model whereby you retain ownership of the component, lease it to your customer, and recover it for remanufacturing or reuse after it has reached end of life.
  4. It is vital to identify where your business has the biggest carbon impact. These departments should then be considered a priority. Remember, your biggest impact could be outside of your head office.

A “Green” team is a group of people working on reduction measures throughout your company. In most cases it’s their additional area of work, aside from their regular work. They are driven by personal values and interest in climate topics.

How to organize the team’s work:

  • conduct meetings at least once a month,
  • offer anyone to join, but ask for a commitment to actively participate,
  • invite senior-level colleagues, representing departments which influence your carbon footprint the most to this team,
  • if more than 10-12 people want to participate, build smaller sub-teams,
  • set objective goals and work on actions that have the biggest impact on your carbon footprint,
  • let all employees know your green team's plans and successes transparently and regularly.

• Develop and implement formal, and job-specific, training on key sustainability issues for all executives and employees, and facilitate coaching, mentoring, and networks for sustainability knowledge sharing.
  • Educate employees about the structure of your footprint and how they can reduce it.
  • Make sure that all new employees go through an induction process and training program to get them involved in your vision of sustainability strategy. It gives everyone a good grasp of what they’re here for and how they can contribute.

Once everyone buys into the vision, you can quantify the environmental impact of various things and bring them to people’s attention. Teams start to see that there are budget implications, staff implications, environmental implications, and resolving this one issue could potentially improve the situation.

Compose your company’s Code of Ethics. Sometimes called a Code of Conduct or Code of Business Standards. This is a formal document that establishes behavioral expectations for the organization and the people who work there. The cultural aspects of the organization need to align with the behaviors and beliefs congruent with tackling the climate emergency. Integrating the right language when talking about this topic is key. Companies must focus on the positives of taking climate action while communicating with organization members, and avoid using ‘frightening’ or ‘threatening’ language as it can be demotivating and make people increasingly skeptical.
